STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
May 13, 2022
Kellie Oom
DA Blodgett for Children
805 Leonard Avenue, NE
Grand Rapids, MI 49503-1138
RE: License #: CB410201088
DA Blodgett for Children
805 Leonard Avenue, NE
Grand Rapids, MI 49503-1138
Dear Ms. Oom:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
May 12, 2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica Vandenheuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
Sincerely,
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood. Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 342-3721
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12324 Reevaluation
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15 calendar
days before the expiration date of the foster home license.
One of eight open foster home files reviewed did not have documentation the
licensing recommendation was made to the department at least 15 calendar days
before the expiration date of the foster home license.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(b) Documentation that the foster parent is willing to accept
the foster child.
Three of three borrowed home files reviewed did not contain documentation the foster
parent was willing to accept the foster child.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
4/30/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 5/18/2021
R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(b) Initiate a special evaluation of the foster home as soon as
is indicated, based on the information received, but not later
than 7 calendar days after receipt of the information.
One of four special investigations reviewed were not initiated within 7 calendar days
after receipt of the information as required.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
4

(c) Conduct a thorough investigation including all necessary
collateral contacts.
Two of four special investigations reviewed did not contain documentation that a
thorough investigation was conducted.
File one: The report references interviews were completed however there are no
interviews documented.
File two: The report is missing documentation of an interview with foster child and
additional household member.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within 45
calendar days after receipt of the information. If additional time is
required, then the agency shall inform the foster parent, in
writing, of the basis for the extension and the expected length of
the extension. The total time for the completion of the
investigation shall not exceed 90 calendar days without written
approval from the chief administrator or his or her designee.
Three of four special investigations reviewed did not contain documentation the foster
parent was notified of the need for an extension and/or did not contain written
approval from the chief administrator the investigation exceeded 90 calendar days.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an agency
shall complete a written report that includes all of the following
information:
(e) Findings of facts, based upon the evaluation.
One of four special investigations reviewed did not contain accurate findings of fact
based on the information gathered.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report required
by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days of its
completion.
5

Two of four special investigations reviewed did not contain documentation the foster
parent was provided a copy of the report within 10 calendar days of completion as
required.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Four of eight open foster care files reviewed contained service plans that were not
completed timely.
File one: USP due on 8/12/2021 was submitted late (8/13/21)
File two: USP due on 2/13/2022 was submitted late (2/14/22)
File three: ISP due on 12/10/2021 was submitted late (12/17/2021)
File four: USP due on 12/22/2021 was submitted late (1/4/2022)
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
4/30/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 5/18/2021
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-08E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary
The caseworker must complete the DHS 69 Foster Care/Juvenile
Justice Action Summary and upload to MISACWIS within the
timeframe required for the specified action/change.
Two of eight open foster care files reviewed did not have the DHS 69 Action Summary
forms completed as required.
FOM 722-08A Supervisor approval
The supervisor must review and approve the service plan within
14 calendar days of the report date.
6

One of eight open foster care files reviewed contained service plans that were not
approved within 14 calendar days of the report date as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/4/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 5/19/2020
4/30/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 5/18/2021
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTM’s must occur within the required time frames as outlines in
the following:
Eight of eight open foster care files reviewed did not have FTM’s completed as
required.
File one: There is not a corresponding FTM in the case file for 2/8/2022 USP.
File two: There is not a corresponding FTM in the case file for 7/9/2021 USP,
10/7/2021 USP and 1/5/2022 USP.
File three: There is not a corresponding FTM in the case file for 8/3/2021 USP and
1/30/2022 USP.
File four: There is not a corresponding FTM for 7/6/2021 USP.
File five: There are no corresponding FTM's prior to or following placement changes
File six: There are no corresponding FTM's prior to or following all of the placement
changes.
File seven: There is not a corresponding FTM for 1/4/2022 USP.
File eight: There is not a corresponding FTM for 7/22/2021 USP, 10/11/2021 USP and
1/4/2022 USP.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/4/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 5/19/2020
4/30/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 5/18/2021
FOM 722-06B FTM documentation
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is used to capture
family demographics, FTM logistical information, needs,
strengths, action steps, safety concerns and the safety plan, and
any recommendations made for the family during the FTM. The
DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM. The
caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS using
the FTM hyperlink within seven business days of the FTM.
Eight of eight open foster care files reviewed did not have the DHS-1105 form or it
was not uploaded timely.
7

FOM 801-03 Medical Passport
Initial Medical Passport
For children entering foster care, the initial medical passport must
be provided within two weeks of the child/youth's placement date
to the following:
 Foster care provider.
Updated Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's current
and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary court
ward.
Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider:
At or prior to each placement.
Quarterly.
Six of eight open foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports as
required.
File one: Initial medical passport not provided within 14 days of removal. Child
removed on 4/15/2021 and initial medical passport provided on 5/11/1021.
File two: There are no medical passports between 6/30/2021-1/31/2022.
File three: There are no medical passports between 8/22/2021-4/18/2022.
File four: There are no medical passports since 10/20/2021.
File five: The medical passport was not provided following placement changes.
File six: There are no medical passports since 7/1/2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/4/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 5/19/2020
4/30/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 5/18/2021
8

FOM 722-08D Foster Care Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth aged 14 and older and in the
case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS office
designee.
Five of eight open foster care files reviewed did not contain all required signatures on
PATP’s or documentation as to why it could not be obtained.
File one: 5/6/2021 PATP caregiver signature not obtained timely and missing mother's
signature; 11/1/2021 PATP missing caregiver signature.
File two: 7/6/2021 PATP missing caregiver, youth, and mother's signature; 10/4/2021
PATP signatures not obtained timely (mother: 11/18/2021, child and FP: 11/15/2021),
11/15/2021 PATP missing youth and FP signature; 2/14/22 PATP missing mother's
signature, child's PATP not uploaded so unable to verify signatures.
File three: 3/3/2022 PATP missing mother's signature.
File four: 9/23/2021 PATP signatures not obtained timely (11/10/2021).
File five: 7/22/2021 PATP FP signature obtained late (8/30/2021); 1/4/2022 PATP not
mailed to dad timely (2/14/2022), FP not uploaded so unable to verify signature.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/4/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 5/19/2020
4/30/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 5/18/2021; previously under ISEP 6.19
FOM 722-06H Case contacts
Timely entry of case contacts
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face contacts
listed below in MISACWIS within five business days of the
contact. This includes attempted and missed face-to-face
contacts.
Five of eight open foster care files reviewed contained case contacts that were not
entered within five business days as required.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
 Reminder to make sure PATP signatures include date.
 Follow up with staff who are submitting reports on the due date and
immediately recalling to complete unfinished work.
 Upload any help desk tickets or emails to show there were issues that may
have caused delays.
9

 Recommendation for agency to reevaluate special investigation
process/checklist. In addition, recommendation for licensing supervisors to
attend refresher training (certification/complaint training) to assist with
compliance with special investigations moving forward.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
The facility did not request consultation during this review.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period in response to the interim
inspection completed on 4/30/2021 with a corrective action plan approved on
5/18/2021. During the review the agency had twenty-four violations. Six citations
were noted as repeat violations in the current inspection. During this period under
review the agency expressed the impact that the COVID-19 pandemic had on
overall compliance. In addition, the agency noted that staff turnover and retention
impacted overall compliance.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported the agency’s difficulty in meeting certain requirements
during this review period. The Chief Administrator stated the previous years CAP was
effective and continues to be utilized, however increased staff turnover during the
past year has been challenging. Specifically, the assessment noted turnover involving
foster care staff has been ongoing, this past year the agency has experienced
turnover at every level. In addition, the agency has held case management
responsibility over some very challenging cases that involved higher than average
replacements.
The Chief Administrator indicated that support for staff and supervisors has been a
priority. In addition, the agency continues to seek alternative and creative means to
ensure continued compliance. The Chief Administrator expressed confidence that
several areas will improve over the next review period.
Interviews
Interviews were conducted with five staff via telephone. Staff acknowledged this year
has been difficult due to COVID-19 and staffing issues. However, they continue to
adjust and anticipate improvement. Specifically working in the office more has been
helpful. In addition, staff reported being hopeful some of the staffing challenges will
improve over the upcoming review period. Staff reported several challenging cases
over the past review period but reported feeling supported by supervision as well as
co-workers.
10

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Field Analyst identified two safety concerns as follows:
Safety Alert #1: Unlicensed relative did not have a medical authorization card for the
child placed in the home.
Resolution: The agency provided a medical card via email and USPS mail to the
unlicensed relative within 24 hours and provided a copy of the email to the Field
Analyst as verification.
Safety Alert #2: Unlicensed relative was in need of batteries for smoke detector.
Resolution: Agency purchased battery operated smoke detector with battery included
from Amazon on 4/1/2022. Licensing supervisor spoke with unlicensed relative who
reported she purchased new batteries for smoke detector on the date of Field Analyst
visit. On 4/15/2022 Adoption worker conducted a scheduled home visit and verified
the smoke detector was in working order.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
___________5/13/2022__________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
May 13, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
